title: Mounting Interest in Australia’s Historic Town of Macedon
text:
Heritage realtor Dominic Romeo and his interior designer wife, Marie, expect to be inundated with inquiries on the country getaway they listed for sale in the historic township of Macedon.

It’s on a rare 10 acres of stunning English-style gardens, 40 miles northwest of Melbourne, Victoria, surrounded by a picket fence with crisp white-and-blue interiors for a country-chic finish.

“It’s a house we bought about four years ago, brick veneer, run down and covered in blackberries,” Mr. Romeo said.

More: Australian Businessman John Symond Selling Yacht for €97.5 Million

“We’ve turned it into a real lifestyle property. It’s got five bedrooms, four bathrooms, new barns, a garage, [chicken] sheds, all designed in a colonial style,” he said. “You don’t get too many homes where everything has been done to and [you] can just walk in and enjoy it. Plus the price range is very realistic for something of that quality.”

As restorers of country houses for more than three decades—the couple authored the best-selling “Constant Renovators” three years ago—the home on Mount Macedon Road, Macedon, is in the heart of a regional Australian hotspot, where prices have increased about 35% in the past three years.

The French-provincial style Lindenbury on Mount Macedon Road has been transformed into a resort-style escape with swimming pool and conservatory. It is seeking offers between A$4 million and A$4.4 million with Abercromby's Real Estate. Abercromby's Real Estate

Real Estate Institute of Victoria, or REIV, data shows the median house price in the Macedon Ranges’ township passed A$1million (US$670,000) in the 12 months to June 30, although only three sales were recorded during that time.

The three Mount Macedon transactions ranged from A$680,000 to A$1.687 million.

More: Olivia Newton-John’s Longtime Australian Farm Finds a Buyer

“Mount Macedon is the jewel in the region’s property market and definitely has a certain ‘star appeal’ with high-flying business people, celebrities and politicians choosing it as their tranquil weekend or holiday base in recent years,” REIV chief executive officer Gil King said.



“The fact that the Real Estate Institute of Victoria only has three sales [on record] for Mount Macedon in the last financial year shows that properties in the area are in strong demand and tightly held,” he continued.

“The town’s beauty, relaxed lifestyle and relative proximity to the city all contribute to making the heart of the Macedon Ranges home to some of Victoria’s most coveted real estate,” Mr. King said.

More: Fig Tree Pocket: A Sleepy, High-End Enclave in Brisbane

Historic Getaway

Natural beauty and its cool summer climate attracted Melbourne’s wealthy social elite to the slopes of Mount Macedon in the late 1870s. As the highest peak of the Macedon Ranges, it is an area of significant history with immense scenic and environmental values.



Rich in English-style horticulture and architecture, timbergetters were the first Europeans to occupy the area, using wood in the goldfields and to construct some of Melbourne’s earliest homes in the 1850s. When the Victorian government released blocks of land on Mount Macedon’s southern slopes in the 1870s, several grand Victorian homes were built as summer residences.

Serial renovator Brenda Tocher and her partner, Jim Moser, had never heard of the area until a work colleague tipped them off in 2015.

Taking a drive one weekend, they were instantly transfixed, buying a French-inspired estate called Lindenbury, on Mount Macedon Road, and transforming it into the all-season home that stands today.

Surrounded by established gardens and Australian bushland, the house has six bedrooms, four bathrooms and a new glass conservatory with underfloor heating and wood fireplace.

“As we came off the freeway and hit the bottom of Mount Macedon Road, even before we had arrived at the Golden Mile as people call it, I said to Jim ‘this is it’,” Ms. Tocher said of her first reaction to the area.

“It was perfect; it felt absolutely right,” she added. “It’s very beautiful, there’s a pub on the main street and a trading post and that’s about it. That’s all you need.”

The Australian Bureau of Statistics shows Mount Macedon’s residents’ average age is 47, and one-third of the 650 households in the suburb earn a gross weekly income of more than A$3,000.

More: Beaming ‘Sunshine’: This Australia Beach Town is Bucking the National Trend

It has the highest number of 19century gardens in the southern hemisphere and 10 parks, which cover more than 45% of its land area.

Mr. Romeo said a younger generation is discovering the area, as families seek the romance of a rural lifestyle in an area rich with amenities such as quality schools, galleries and cafes.

“I deal with a lot of people buying weekenders, usually they’re younger couples in their 30s and 40s, and they’re buying but keeping their Melbourne property as the weekender,” he said.

“It’s a very culturally, environmentally and historically rich region,” Mr. Romeo added. “A lot of young families moving in want their children to experience a safe country life, where kids can walk to school and everyone knows everyone. It has a real sense of community.”

More: Resort Styling Making Strides in Australia

“Even though the market in Melbourne and Sydney has slowed down, the market around the Macedon Ranges has been quite strong because there’s still movement from families wanting to get out of the city,” he said. “They want to sell out and buy something that’s a little bit unique.”

Prestige Listings

Of the 18 lifestyle properties listed for sale with asking prices of more than A$1 million in Mount Macedon, none is more coveted than a home on Mount Macedon Road known as Cameron Lodge, which has an asking price range of A$7.5 million to A$8.25 million.

Cameron Lodge at on Mount Macedon Road, is the suburb's most coveted address and is on the market with Abercromby's Real Estate with an asking price range of A$7.5 to A$8.25 million. Abercromby's Real Estate

Abercromby’s Real Estate agent Jock Langley is selling the Indian Colonial-style home, which is surrounded by gardens that date back to 1886, with the area’s enviable array of prestige properties adding an air of exclusivity.

“There’s been a resurgence in that area because people have realized it’s so accessible to Melbourne, and it’s become a real destination for its gastro experiences, an enviable lifestyle and small acreage lots or hobby farms,” he said.

More: Sydney Mansion With Iconic Harbor Views Lists for A$60 Million

“You get more bang for your buck in Mount Macedon and there’s so much history to the area.” Mr. Langley continued. “There’s real appeal from people in Melbourne wanting to invest in that scene.”

The most glamorous and dramatic of the area’s current prestige listings is a home on Tucketts Road, Mount Macedon, constructed predominantly from a palette of Castlemaine sandstone, ironbark timber and copper 10 years ago.

The five-bedroom house on 20 acres has an asking price range of A$5.4million to A$5.9 million and was co-listed with WHITEFOX Real Estate and Lindsay Hill Real Estate in December 2018.

On Tucketts Road in Mount Macedon is an acclaimed architectural home with 20 acres of land and expansive valley and mountain views that's listed for sale with an asking price of A$5.4million to A$5.9million. Tony Mein

Designed by Geelong architectural practice Studio 101, the highly acclaimed house was featured in “Pure Luxury, the World’s 100 Best Houses” book, published in 2012.

The resort-style Lindenbury, also on Mount Macedon Road, is listed for A$4million to A$4.4 million with Abercromby’s Real Estate, while a modern marvel also on Mount Macedon Road, for sale through Circa Heritage and Lifestyle, has an asking price range of A$2.95 million to A$3.1million.

More: The Australian Ranch: A Unique Lifestyle and a Smart Investment

Cawdor is a newly listed country lifestyle property at on Mount Macedon, Macedon, which is being sold by Circa Heritage and Lifestyle for A$2.25million and $2.4million. Circa Heritage and Lifestyle

“Mount Macedon isn’t just beautiful, it’s culturally important,” Mr. Romeo said. “You can’t just buy five acres to then subdivide or split up. It’s heavily protected. That’s why people move here, their lifestyle is protected and there isn’t a fear that a block of units is suddenly going to go up. That way it retains it exclusivity.”
